leg:heading.title: TABLE OF AMENDMENTS

p.text: The Supreme Court (Summary Jurisdiction) Act No 72 of 1967 received assent on 7 December 1967 and commenced 18 January 1974. It was repealed by the Justices Legislation Repeal and Amendment Act No 121 of 2001 which commenced 7 July 2003. Amendments to this Act are listed below.

row.entry: 1 July 1972 (except Part IX) (Gaz 59 of 2 June 1972 p 2018)

Order dated 22 May 1978 (Gaz 58 of 26 May 1978 p 1989). (a) Supreme Court (Summary Jurisdiction) Act 1967 is an enactment to which s 8(2) of the Acts Reprinting Act 1972 applies; and (b) Supreme Court (Summary Jurisdiction) Act 1967 the words “of this subsection” in s 5(1) excepted, is an enactment to which s 9(3) of the Acts Reprinting Act 1972, applies.
Supreme Court (Summary Jurisdiction) Bail (Amendment) Act 1978 No 164
Sch 1: 17 March 1980, s 2(2) (Gaz 45 of 14 March 1980 p 1143)
Supreme Court (Summary Jurisdiction) Crimes (Amendment) Act 1979 No 96
Sch 1: 12 November 1979, s 2(3) (Gaz 148 of 2 November 1979 p 5451)
Justices Legislation Repeal and Amendment Act 2001 No 121

leg:heading.title: SUPREME COURT (SUMMARY JURISDICTION) ACT 1967 [REPEALED]

p.text: AN ACT to confer a summary jurisdiction on the Supreme Court of New South Wales; and for purposes connected therewith.

BE it enacted by the Queen's Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly of New South Wales in Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,000] s 1 Short title and commencement

leg:heading.title: Short title and commencement

p.text: This Act may be cited as the Supreme Court (Summary Jurisdiction) Act 1967.
This Act shall commence upon a day to be appointed by the Governor and notified by proclamation published in the Gazette.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,005] s 2 Interpretation

leg:heading.title: Interpretation

p.text: In this Act, unless inconsistent with the context or subject-matter—
means the Supreme Court of New South Wales.
means Judge of the Court.
means rules made under the Supreme Court Act 1970 .
[s 2 subst Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2 ; am Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,010] s 3 Summary jurisdiction of the Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Summary jurisdiction of the Supreme Court

p.text: Where, under any Act, proceedings for an offence may be taken before the Court in its summary jurisdiction, the Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine those proceedings in a summary manner.
The summary jurisdiction conferred on the Court by subsection 1 of this section shall be exercised by a Judge sitting alone, and not otherwise.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,015] s 4 Orders for appearance or apprehension of defendants

leg:heading.title: Orders for appearance or apprehension of defendants

p.text: Upon an application being made by any person (in this Act referred to as the "prosecutor") in accordance with the rules, a Judge shall make an order—

ordering any person alleged in the application to have committed an offence punishable in the Court in its summary jurisdiction to appear at a time and place specified in the order to answer to the offence charged in the order; or
ordering the apprehension of any such person for the purpose of the person's being brought before a Judge to answer to the offence charged in the order.
[subs (1) am Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2 ; Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
An order under subsection 1 of this section may be made ex parte.

An order in respect of an offence alleged to have been committed by a person may be made under paragraph (b) of subsection 1 of this section whether or not an order in respect of that offence has been made under paragraph (a) of that subsection.
An order under paragraph (b) of subsection 1 of this section—
shall be addressed to all members of the police force;
may be addressed to any other person specified in the order; and

may be executed by any member of the police force or by any person to whom it is addressed at any place at which, had the offence specified in the order been committed at that place, that offence would be triable in the Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,020] s 5 Powers of Judge where defendant apprehended

leg:heading.title: Powers of Judge where defendant apprehended

p.text: Where any person apprehended pursuant to an order made under section 4(1)(b) is brought before a Judge, the Judge shall, subject to the Bail Act 1978 , by warrant commit the person to prison and order the person to be there detained until the person is brought before a Judge at a time and place specified in the order to answer to the offence with which the person is charged.
[s 5 subst Act 164 of 1978 s 5 and Sch 1 ; am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,025] s 5A Notices to be given to prosecutor

leg:heading.title: Notices to be given to prosecutor

p.text: The Prothonotary shall, as soon as practicable after the making of any order under section 5 , cause notice of the order to be given to the prosecutor.

The Prothonotary shall, as soon as practicable after a notice is given or sent (as referred to in section 34 of the Bail Act 1978) to a person referred to in section 5 , cause a copy of the notice to be given to the prosecutor.
[s 5A insrt Act 164 of 1978 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,030] s 6 Defects and variances in process

leg:heading.title: Defects and variances in process

p.text: No objection shall be taken or allowed to any application referred to in, or to any order or warrant made or issued under, section 4 or 5 of this Act by reason of any alleged defect in it in substance or in form or by reason of any variance between it and the evidence adduced at the proceedings for the offence charged in the application or order.
The Judge hearing the proceedings for any such offence shall—

where it appears to the Judge that any variance between any such application or order and the evidence adduced in respect of the offence charged in the application or order is such that the defendant has been misled by the variance; and
the defendant applies for an adjournment of the hearing, adjourn the hearing.
[subs (2) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,035] s 7 How defendant dealt with during adjournment

leg:heading.title: How defendant dealt with during adjournment

p.text: Where the hearing of the proceedings for an offence punishable in the summary jurisdiction of the Court is adjourned, whether under section 6 or otherwise, the Judge before whom the proceedings are taken may, subject to the Bail Act 1978 , by warrant commit the defendant to prison and order him or her to be there detained until he or she is brought before the Judge at a time and place specified in the order to answer further to the offence with which he or she is charged.
[s 7 subst Act 164 of 1978 s 5 and Sch 1 ; am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,040] s 8 Practice and procedure for taking and receiving evidence

leg:heading.title: Practice and procedure for taking and receiving evidence

p.text: Subject to this Act and the rules, the practice and procedure of the Court in relation to the taking and receiving of evidence at the trial of accused persons on indictment apply to the taking and receiving of evidence in proceedings in the summary jurisdiction of the Court.
[s 8 am Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2 ; Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,045] s 9 Procedure where prosecutor does not, but defendant does appear

leg:heading.title: Procedure where prosecutor does not, but defendant does appear

p.text: If, upon the day and at the time and place appointed by an order made in respect of a defendant under paragraph (a) of subsection (1) of section 4, or under section 5 , of this Act, the prosecutor does not appear in person or by a counsel or attorney, but the defendant attends in accordance with the order and, in the case of an order under section 5 of this Act, the prosecutor has received notice of the order, the Judge shall dismiss the charge unless for some reason the Judge thinks it proper to adjourn the hearing.
[subs (1) am Act 164 of 1978 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

If, upon the day and at the time and place specified in a notice referred to in section 5A(2) , the prosecutor does not appear in person or by a counsel or attorney, but the defendant attends, and the prosecutor has received a copy of the notice, the Judge shall dismiss the charge unless for some reason the Judge thinks it proper to adjourn the hearing.
[subs (2) insrt Act 164 of 1978 s 5 and Sch 1 ; am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,050] s 10 Procedure where defendant does not obey order to appear

leg:heading.title: Procedure where defendant does not obey order to appear

p.text: If, upon the day and at the time and place appointed by an order made in respect of a defendant under paragraph (a) of subsection 1 of section 4 of this Act, the defendant does not appear, then upon proof of the due service, in accordance with the rules of the order upon the defendant at a reasonable time before the time appointed for the defendant's appearance the Judge may either—
proceed to hear and determine the case and adjudicate thereon in the absence of the defendant; or
adjourn the hearing and make an order for the apprehension of the defendant as provided in paragraph (b) of subsection 1 of section 4 of this Act.
[s 10 am Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2 ; Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2 ; Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,055] s 11 Procedure where either party does not appear at adjourned hearing

leg:heading.title: Procedure where either party does not appear at adjourned hearing

p.text: If, upon the day at the time and place to which the hearing or further hearing of a charge has been adjourned, either or both of the parties does not, or do not, appear in person or by a counsel or attorney, the Judge then and there present may proceed with the hearing as if that party or those parties were present, and in a case where it is the prosecutor who does not so appear may dismiss the charge with or without costs.
[subs (1) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
Subsection (1) does not empower the Judge to order costs to be paid in proceedings for an offence referred to in section 475A(1) of the Crimes Act 1900.
[subs (2) insrt Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,060] s 12 Where both parties appear Judge to hear and determine the case

leg:heading.title: Where both parties appear Judge to hear and determine the case

p.text: If, upon the day and at the time and place appointed for hearing or to which the hearing or further hearing has been adjourned, both parties appear in person or by their respective counsel or attorneys the Judge shall proceed to hear the case.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,065] s 13 Provision for hearing cases together

leg:heading.title: Provision for hearing cases together

p.text: Where a defendant is charged with two or more offences punishable in the summary jurisdiction of the Court, whether of a like or different nature, the Judge shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the charges together.
[subs (1) am Act 96 of 1976 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act No 94 of 1999 Sch 4.162]

Where two or more defendants are separately charged with any such offences, whether of a like or different nature, alleged to have been committed at the same time and place, the Judge shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the charges together.
[subs (2) am Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act No 94 of 1999 Sch 4.162]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,070] s 13A Pre-trial procedure

leg:heading.title: Pre-trial procedure

p.text: Nothing in this Act requires the Judge to proceed to hear and determine any case if any prescribed pre-trial procedures which are required by rules made under this Act to be completed before the trial of a case commences have not been completed.
[s 13A insrt Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,075] s 14 Judge may order payment of costs

leg:heading.title: Judge may order payment of costs

p.text: Where a Judge—
convicts any person of an offence punishable in the summary jurisdiction of the Court;
makes an order dismissing the charge for any such offence; or
makes an order under subsection 1 of section 10 of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 in respect of any such offence,

the Judge may, in and by the conviction or order, order the defendant, in the case of a conviction or order referred to in paragraph (a) or (c) of this subsection, to pay to the prosecutor, or, in the case of an order referred to in paragraph (b) of this subsection, order the prosecutor to pay to the defendant, such costs as to the Judge seem just and reasonable.
[subs (1) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 93 of 2000 Sch 2 ]
The amount so ordered to be paid for costs shall in all cases be specified in the conviction or order.
Subsection (1) does not empower the Judge to order costs to be paid in proceedings for an offence referred to section 475A(1) of the Crimes Act 1900.
[subs (3) insrt Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,080] s 15 Enforcement of fines or orders

leg:heading.title: Enforcement of fines or orders

p.text: The payment of any money ordered by a Judge exercising summary jurisdiction under this Act to be paid as a penalty or for costs may be enforced in accordance with the Fines Act 1996 .
[s 15 subst Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2 ; Act 99 of 1996 s 130 and Sch 2]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,085] s 16 Payment by instalments, or security taken for payment of moneys

leg:heading.title: Payment by instalments, or security taken for payment of moneys

p.text: The Judge by whose conviction or order any moneys are ordered to be paid may in and by such conviction or order do all or any of the following things, namely,—
allow time for the payment of the moneys;
direct payment to be made of the moneys by instalments;
direct that the person liable to pay the moneys may give to the satisfaction of the Judge security, with or without a surety or sureties, for the payment of the moneys or of any instalment thereof.
A security referred to in paragraph (c) of subsection 1 of this section shall be in such form and may be enforced in such manner as may be prescribed by the rules.
[subs (2) am Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2 ; am Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2]

Where any such moneys are directed to be paid by instalments, and default is made in the payment of any one instalment, the same proceedings may be taken as if default had been made in payment of all the instalments then remaining unpaid.

A Judge directing the payment of any such moneys or of an instalment of any such moneys, may direct the payment to be made at such time or times, and in such place or places, and to such person or persons, as may be specified by the Judge in the direction and every person to whom any such moneys or instalment are or is paid, if he or she is not the person entitled to enforce the payment, shall, as soon as is practicable, account for and pay the moneys or instalments to that person.
[subs (4) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,090] s 17 Aiding abetting counselling or procuring the commission of offences

leg:heading.title: Aiding abetting counselling or procuring the commission of offences

p.text: A person who aids, abets, counsels or procures the commission by another person of an offence punishable in the summary jurisdiction of the Court is guilty of the like offence and may be tried at the same time as or before or after the trial of the principal offender.
[ss 18–24, 26 rep Act 96 of 1979 ss 5, 6 and Sch 1; s 25 rep Act 164 of 1978 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,095] s 26A Release of appellant and stay of conviction or order

leg:heading.title: Release of appellant and stay of conviction or order

p.text: [s 26A rep Act 96 of 1979 s 6]
[s 27 rep Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2; s 28 rep Act 96 of 1979 s 6 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,110] s 28A Termination of petty sessions proceedings upon commencement of proceedings under this Act

leg:heading.title: Termination of petty sessions proceedings upon commencement of proceedings under this Act

p.text: Any proceedings in a Local Court for an offence for which proceedings may be taken either under this Act or before a Local Court shall be terminated upon the Local Court being notified, in accordance with the rules, of the commencement of proceedings under this Act for that offence.
[s 28A subst Act 96 of 1979 s 6 and Sch 1 ; am Act 31 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 4]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [430,115] s 28B Effect of convictions under this Act

leg:heading.title: Effect of convictions under this Act

p.text: A conviction under this Act for an offence—
[Repealed ]
[s 28B(a) insrt Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1 ; rep Act No 94 of 1999 Sch 4.162]
that is of a kind that may be tried either on indictment or under this Act shall be deemed for all purposes, except the Criminal Appeal Act 1912 , to be a conviction on indictment.
[s 28B(b) insrt Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:heading.title: Rules

p.text: Rules may be made under the Supreme Court Act 1970 , for or with respect to the practice and procedure of the Court in the exercise of its summary jurisdiction.
[subs (1) am Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2]
Without limiting the generality of subsection 1 of this section the rules may make provision for or with respect to—
pre-trial procedures in any proceedings in the Court in the exercise of its summary jurisdiction and practice with respect thereto;
the attendance or apprehension of defendants and witnesses;
the examination of witnesses on oath, affirmation or declaration;
the production by witnesses of books, documents and writings;
the execution of warrants for the apprehension of any person;

any matter which by this Act is required to be prescribed by rules or which is necessary or convenient for carrying out or giving effect to the provisions of this Act relating to the summary jurisdiction of the Court.
[subs (2) am Act 52 of 1970 s 7 and Sch 2 ; Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2 ; Act 96 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]
The rules shall—
be published in the Gazette;
take effect from the date of publication or from a later date specified in the rules;

be laid before both Houses of Parliament within fourteen sitting days after publication if Parliament is in session or, if not, then within fourteen sitting days after the commencement of the next session.
[subs (4) rep Act 41 of 1972 s 14 and Sch 2]
